Award.AwardTitle: RUI: New methods for chemical sialylation: an O-protecting group approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Cristina DeMeo of the Southern Illinois University Edwardsville is investigating structural modifications of sialic acid derivatives. Sialic acids are carbohydrates which are involved in numerous biological phenomena, ranging from cell-cell adhesion and mobility to oncogenesis and recognition by viruses and bacteria. The broader impacts include advancing the chemistry of sialic acids, enabling access to important biologically active sialic acids, and training undergraduate and Master's students, with an emphasis on recruiting and training underrepresented minorities.

Sialylations by chemical methods are often complicated by the intrinsic structural features of sialic acids, making the stereoselective synthesis of sialosides a challenge in carbohydrate chemistry. With the ultimate goal of gaining a better understanding of the roles of O-protecting groups in sialylations, this project is centered on the evaluation of sialyl donors functionalized at O-4 and O-7 positions. In addition, the research is addressing the influence of protecting groups at O-4 and N-5 on the conformation of sialic acids.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The assembly of carbohydrates, which are present in our cell’s surface. is essential to study their biological functions as well as to design drugs or vaccines. Our research group has been focused on the development of methodologies for the synthesis of carbohydrates containing one specific sugar, sialic acid.  The development of such methodologies is an important contribution in the advancement of therapeutic solutions for diseases such as cancer, or pathogen attacks such as influenza.  In particular, the project supported by this funding, investigated the chemical influence upon the introduction of a specific group (Pico) in sialic acid. During the granting period we introduced Pico groups at several positions in sialic acid and observed the effect in sialylations. We are pleased to report that we noticed an improvement in the general outcome of these reactions when compared to benchmarks. We also noticed an unusual dependency of this modification to the amount of triflic acid used. The intellectual merit resulting from the data so collected, lies in the development of a new methodology for the assembly of oligosaccharides of biological relevance. The data collected in this project has been reported in several local, national and international symposia, as well as published in peer reviewed journals. Broader impact associated with this project has been the training of undergraduate and Master students in sialic acid chemistry. The field is itself quite attractive as it falls between organic chemistry and biomedical science. However, in many cases, the time that undergraduate students can commit in working in the lab is limited not just by their class load, but especially by the additional jobs that they need to have in order to maintain themselves in college.  This is particularly typical of minority students who in general come from more disadvantaged families. Thus, the ability of financially support students is essential: by giving them the opportunity to do research and to acquire important skills, they are more competitive in the work field and therefore they have higher chances to be successful. Least but not last, the financial travel support given to my students by attending and presenting at national and international symposia was an eye opening event. The realization of the impact of their work in a larger scheme strengthened their motivation and passion. Almost all the students involved in this project carried on to a higher education position (Master or PhD).  And for many, the decision to move forward was largely or solely due to their overall experiences as researchers.

On the practical standpoint, working in an undergraduate institution with undergraduate and Master students, the project linked to this grant produced: four publications, several symposia presentations (posters and oral); six students moving towards PhD career, one student at Sigma Millipore, and several undergraduate students into Master Degree. Regardless, the most successful story of all, was for me the opportunity to help a student living in his car and working overnight in Walmart to switch life gear by being hired to work in the lab as well as in the department.  From him and all the other research students of my group I report also a sincere gratitude to NSF.
